title: Geographic Information Systems
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course discusses the principles, structure and application of geographic information systems. It emphasizes on the use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to organize and manage spatial data, and how to perform spatial analysis with GIS. Topics include: GPS data acquisition, georelational data model, raster and vector data structures, spatial database, spatial analysis and application issues.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to:- Understand the essence of spatial data modelling, spatial analysis skills, navigation and positioning techniques, latest development trends, GIS applications and project management;- Gain experiences in investigating and solving real problems using GIS through practices and final project.
syllabus: Topics include: GPS data acquisition, georelational data model, raster and vector data structures, spatial database, spatial analysis and application issues.

title: GIS-T and Logistical Information Management
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course focuses on how geographic information systems (GIS) can be used to support various applications in transportation and logistics. This course covers such topics as shortest paths, routing, network flows, facility location, travel demand analysis, and intelligent transportation systems. Students will use TransCAD (Caliper Corp.) and ArcGIS (ESRI) in this course to gain hands-on experience with GIS-T. The main course objective is to help students gain a better understanding of GIS-T concepts and GIS-T applications.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to: - Understand the principles of applying GIS to the areas of transportation and logistics; - Gain familiarity with the use of GIS-T tools; - Develop competence in implementing an application of GIS for transportation or logistics.
syllabus: 1 Introduction to GIS-T Sept 82+3 Network Representations 4+5 Shortest Path Problem 6 Linear Referencing Systems (LRS) and Dynamic segmentation 7 Location-Allocation Models 8 Network Flow Models 9 Transportation Planning 10 Activity-travel analysis 11 Transportation Demand Management

title: Digital Remote Sensing Image Analysis
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course discusses the principles and applications of remote sensing image analysis. Topics include principle of remote sensing, acquisition of satellite imagery, format of digital images, digital image processing systems, image display, geometric correction, radiometric adjustment, image enhancement, image classification, accuracy verification, change detection, and orthophoto applications. This course is taught with both lectures and laboratories. Lectures will be accompanied by laboratories for students to grasp both the theoretical and practical issues in remote sensing image analysis.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to:  - Understand the principles of satellite remote sensing; - Learn the techniques of digital image analysis; - Understand how digital image analysis is being used in geographical studies.

title: Applied Remote Sensing
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course discusses various applications of remote sensing image analysis. The course begins by introducing the basic principle of remote sensing and an overview of remote sensing applications. On one hand, individual topics covering the application of remote sensing in vegetation, urban landscape, water and hydrology are discussed. On the other hand, various kinds of remotely-sensed data including high-resolution, thermal, hyperspectral, radar are introduced. This course is taught with lectures, laboratories and individual projects. Lectures will be accompanied by laboratories for students to grasp both the theoretical and application issues of remote sensing. Students are required to initiate, present and submit individual project to complete the course requirement.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to: - Understand the application of remote sensing data in different aspects of the environment including vegetation, urban landscape and water; - Learn the skills in processing and analysing different types of remote sensing data; - Extract initial statistics and thematic information from different data. • Acquire advanced knowledge and skills in classification problems
syllabus: 1) Principle of radiative transfer 2) Image spectrometry 3) Thermal infrared remote sensing and applications 4) Radar remote sensing and applications 5) Airborne remote sensing  6) Advanced vegetation mapping/ classification 7) Vegetation biophysical parameter estimation 8) Water remote sensing and hydrological applications 9) Image fusion and feature selection 10) Advanced classification algorithms

title: Global Positioning Systems
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course covers the basic principles of Global Positioning Systems (GPS): observables, error sources and their reduction, and positioning techniques. Other systems of Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) will also be introduced. Applications of GNSS in various fields will be discussed, including navigation, Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS), Location Based Services (LBS), engineering, and atmosphere sensing. Through hands-on exercises, students will learn how to use GPS devices to collect data in the field in support of various geospatial applications.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Smart Cities
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course aims at the concepts and applications of artificial intelligence in solving real-life problems in Smart-City management. Fundamentals of artificial intelligence methods for decision making will be discussed. It covers various paradigms for artificial-intelligence applications in spatial knowledge representation and inference, computational models and intelligent spatial decision support systems (SDSS). The enrichment of spatial decision support by data mining and knowledge discovery will also be examined. Open-source artificial intelligence software systems will be introduced to facilitate discussions, and to assist students to acquire hands-on experience of the relevant knowledge.
outcome: The emphasis of this course is placed on the fundamentals of artificial intelligence methods for developing decision support systems and the hands-on experience in using and designingdecision support systems for smart-city management. After taking the course, students are expected to:- Understand the basic concepts of artificial intelligence methods;- Know the basic paradigms for knowledge representation and inference based on artificial intelligence methods;- Use in-house spatial decision support system (SDSS) tool to develop simple SDSS.

title: Urban Environmental Modeling and Simulation
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course covers major concepts and methods for modeling spatial patterns and processes. Topics include cellular automata, agent-based models, terrain modeling, spatio-temporal data modeling, integration of GIS and environmental modeling, noise modeling, modeling of watershed hydrology and water quality and other relevant applications. During the course, students will learn about different modeling approaches and their applications and work on lab exercises and course projects.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to: - Develop an understanding of geospatial modeling and simulation methods; - Evaluate the trade-offs among different modeling and simulation methods; - Demonstrate a working knowledge to solve real-world geographical issues using the methods learned.

title: Design and Implementation of Geographical Information Systems
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course covers the basic principles for GIS design and application system implementation using the mainstream techniques. Topics include requirement analysis, object-oriented design using Unified Modeling Language (UML), database normalization, and GIS customization within a GIS environment. Students will develop their competence in designing and customizing GIS tools through lectures, hands-on lab exercises, and a course project.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to: - Understand the principles of GIS Design using Structured System Analysis and Design Method; - Gain familiarity with the methods for customizing GIS; - Develop competence in implementing a GIS-based application system.

title: Statistical Analysis of Geographical Data
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course provides an introduction to the basic and spatial statistical analysis methods that are commonly used to investigate geographically represented data. Topics covered include: (1) correlation analysis, (2) principal components analysis, (3) cluster analysis, (4) Geostatistical analysis, and (5) global and local spatial regression models. Students will develop their competency in using and applying GIS and statistical tools to solve real-world geographical problems through hands-on lab exercises and course projects.
outcome: At the end of this course, students are expected to: • Understand the principles of basic statistics and spatial statistics, • Develop proficiency in using GIS and statistical tools relevant to the principles covered, and • Apply the knowledge to analyze real-world geographical problems
syllabus: 1. Geographical data manipulation 2. Correlation and spatial autocorrelation analysis 3. Linear and stepwise regression analysis 4. Logistic regression analysis 5. Principal component analysis 6. Factor analysis 7. Canonical correlation analysis  8. Cluster analysis 9. Discriminant analysis 10. Spatial regression models 11. Geographically weighted regression analysis 12. Geostatistical Kriging models 13. Presentations by postgraduates

title: Geospatial Big Data for Smart Urban Planning
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: This course introduces to students geospatial big data (e.g., social media and GPS trajectories) and their applications in urban planning, including land functionality classification, environmental monitoring, sentiment analysis, and transportation planning. The use of GIS in various urban applications relevant to big data will also be covered. These applications encompass urban form, public health, 3D GIS, and geodesign. Through hands-on lab exercises such as data crawling from the web, 3D urban model construction using CityEngine, and geodesign using Geoplanner, students are expected to understand how geospatial big data can be applied to address real-world challenges in the urban environment, and to grasp more advanced skills relating to GIS applications.
outcome: At the end of this course, students are expected to: • Understand the principles of urban planning, big data and 3D GIS. • Develop proficiency in using advanced GIS tools relevant to big data, and • Apply the knowledge to address real-world urban problems with the support of big data and GIS

title: Thesis
requirements: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
description: The master thesis project is a compulsory course of the GISM program. It is not a regular course with modules and exercises, but an individual research project where you present your work in an oral presentation and a scientific written report. Students are required to carry out independent studies of selected topics relevant to Geoinformation Science on a variety of problems under staff supervision. Evaluation is based on the oral presentation and written report.
outcome: The master thesis requires a high degree of independent work as the student is working and guided by a supervisor.  Upon completion of the dissertation, students should be able to:  - Advance the knowledge and understanding of Geoinformation science on a variety of problems, with an analysis or application of geographical or spatial data; - Demonstrate ability to select, design and implement an appropriate application topic in Geoinformation science through independent learning; - Improve the skills on doing a project within a given time frame, applying scientific methodologies with constant critical analysis.
syllabus: A master thesis project should consist of the following moments.1. Finding a suitable subject relevant to the program;2. The finding of and coming to an agreement with your supervisor;3. Setting up a final project-plan, time schedule;4. Performing the research, collecting, analyzing and interpretation of data and results;5. Writing the thesis (e.g. literature review, main body, conclusions);6. Presentation and defending in the master thesis examination;7. Finalizing and publishing the thesis.
required_readings: Relevant references will be provided when necessary.
